{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3322078,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-02T15:22:53.275Z","cooked":"

That is, how are you meeting R409? By joined segments, I mean that the segments along different sides of a robot are joined together, likely with metal angle. The order of joined segment options is the same as the OK parts of Figure 8-7. By different segments, I mean that the segment along one side of the robot is not attached to the adjacent side when removed from the robot. Based on my experience, most teams do all four corners the same way, but if your corners are different, feel free to select all that apply and maybe do a post saying why they are different!

Secondary question - is this different from what you have done in recent years? (and why).

  • joined segments, noodle bent around corner
  • Joined segments, vertical noodle in corner
  • Joined segments, mitered
  • Joined segments, lapped
  • Different Segments, mitered
  • Different Segments, lapped
  • Something else (please post to clarify)
0 voters

Did the new bumper rules forbidding large bumper gaps, or other considerations change the way you fill corners?

  • No
  • Somewhat (feel free to post!)
  • Yes (please post!)

I absolutely expect CD bias. Only people on CD and similar social media would know that saggy bumpers can get you on a DNP list.

Even with that said, the most surprising thing to me so far is that nearly half of respondents are bending noodle around the corner. As I related in the ‚ÄúAre We Doing Bumper Right‚Äù thread, I ‚Äúsqueeze the charmin‚Äù all the way around both top and bottom to verify R408C and R409, and thus know how teams I inspect are filling corners. I don‚Äôt write it down, but I only recall pool noodle bent around the corner once in 7 local events I‚Äôve RI‚Äôd (Bayou (3), Arkansas (2) , Magnolia(1) , and Talahassee(1)), and maybe three or four times combined at two CMPs. [Out of about 24 teams I inspected bumpers; you get to inspect way more robots per event at CMP, because all the robots have been inspected already and there aren‚Äôt nearly as many showstopper issues.]

Let‚Äôs be honest, 2018 isn‚Äôt nearly as old enough to be such a trend.

With robot reveals as my primary source, my data is already biased‚Ä¶ but I think it‚Äôs probably safe to say bending noodles around corners became a West Coast thing. Maybe someone else invented it, but the further back you go, the less information there is archived, not to mention the quality of whatever video.

I primarily reviewed 118, 148, 254, and 1678.

148 in 2010 is probably the earliest sign of the bend, but they had a weird bumper that year.

254 definitely had a bend in 2011. It‚Äôs highly probable that they had a full one-piece with bends in 2010, but it‚Äôs hard to tell from match videos. They‚Äôve been bending ever since‚Ä¶ but as of this post, we don‚Äôt know what they have for 2024.

118 didn‚Äôt seem to pick up on bending until 2016, which also happens to be an octagonal shape. This was probably also their first one piece bumper, considering previous years were multi segments. It doesn‚Äôt seem like they bent in 2017, but they did in 2018.

For 1678, they had reversible in 2012, so it‚Äôs not too clear if they bent; they‚Äôve bent since 2013.

Other teams:
971‚Äôs first bend seems to be 2012 (bottom left corner).

Even 1323 in 2011 had bent bumpers

It looks better it seems. We tried bend around the corner this year and it does seem a little less cushioned there.

Unfortunately, we got caught by the bumper gap rule. They were trying to remove a little bumper because originally the gapless version wouldn‚Äôt go on because it needed a slight tilt that caused them to hit each other. But removing material, now we have like a 1" gap instead of <0.5". It is a hard mistake to fix with the tight tolerance.
